bestBHT.bht: How can you, with such audacity, say to your brother, Let me remove the speck from your eye, when you have a beam in your own eye? Are you so blind that you fail to see your own greater sinfulness? How can you have the gall to condemn and criticize others when you are guilty of far worse offenses yourself? May you consider your own faults before attempting to correct others.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: 4. Or how wilt thou say to thy
brother, Let me pull out the mote out of thine eye; and, behold, a
beam is in thine own eye?
John Gill: How canst thou say to thy brother... let me pull out the mote out of thine eye... and behold a beam is in thine own eye."
Thou art guilty of a far greater iniquity: astonishing impudence!
Art thou so blind, as not to see and observe thy viler wickedness? Or which, if conscious of, how canst thou prevail upon thyself to take upon thee to reprove and censure others?
John Wesley: How sayest thou — With what face?

bhtAttempts.bht: How can you, with such audacity, criticize and offer to remove a small speck from your brother’s eye, when you have a much larger flaw of your own? Are you so blind that you cannot even recognize and acknowledge your own greater wickedness? How can you have the nerve to reprove and condemn others when you yourself are guilty of a far greater iniquity? With what audacity do you speak?

How can you audaciously tell your brother to remove a small speck from his eye when you have a massive beam obstructing your own vision? Are you not aware of your own hypocrisy and wickedness? Your impudence in criticizing others while being blind to your own faults is astounding.

How can you, with such audacity, say to your brother, Let me remove the speck from your eye, when you have a beam in your own eye? Are you so blind that you fail to see your own greater sinfulness? How can you have the gall to condemn and criticize others when you are guilty of far worse offenses yourself? May you consider your own faults before attempting to correct others.

How can you, with such audacity and blindness, dare to tell your brother to remove a speck from his eye when you yourself are unaware of the massive beam that obstructs your own vision? You are guilty of a far greater sin, displaying astonishing impudence and a lack of self-awareness. Are you so blind that you cannot see your own wickedness? How can you even begin to have the audacity to reprove and criticize others when you are guilty of the very same or even worse offenses? Your words lack credibility and are devoid of any moral ground to stand on.

How can you, with astonishing impudence, say to your brother, Let me remove the speck from your eye, when you fail to recognize the beam that obstructs your own vision? Your blindness to your own wickedness is astounding. How can you possibly have the audacity to reprove others when you are guilty of the same or even worse offenses? Your words lack credibility and are devoid of any moral ground.
